description:
Torque teno virus 20 (TTV20) is a small, non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA virus that belongs to the Anelloviridae family. It is one of the numerous Torque teno virus (TTV) species that have been identified in various human and animal populations worldwide.

TTV20 is a circular, negative-sense, single-stranded DNA virus with a genome size of approximately 3.2 kilobases. The viral genome encodes several open reading frames (ORFs) that are involved in the expression of viral proteins, including the viral capsid and regulatory proteins.

TTV20, like other TTV species, is considered a ubiquitous virus, meaning it is widely distributed and can be found in the majority of human populations. The virus is believed to be transmitted through various routes, including respiratory droplets, fecal-oral transmission, and potentially vertical transmission from mother to child.

The clinical significance of TTV20 infection is not yet fully understood, as it is often found in both healthy individuals and those with various medical conditions. Some studies have suggested potential associations between TTV20 and certain diseases, but more research is needed to elucidate the exact role, if any, of this virus in human health and disease.
